channel.title: Quadratics
channel.description:
So, after yesterday experimenting around I kept trying to learn more into Python. Late last night my little brother needed some help in Alg2, he was doing Quadratic Equations with real and complex numbers. I thought that would be a nice project to work on trying to solve these in code.
One Problem though, I can't seem to make both complex and real numbers a possibility in one program. I have found out how to get it to spit out real numbers, importing the math module: [code=python]#Solves Quadratic equation # ax**2(ax'squared') + bx + c = 0
#import real numbers import math
a = float(input("Enter a: ")) b = float(input("Enter b: ")) c = float(input("Enter c: "))
#Finds the Discriminant d = (b**2) - (4*a*c)
#finds solutions solt1 = (-b-math.sqrt(d))/(2*a) solt2 = (-b+math.sqrt(d))/(2*a) print "The Discriminant is", d print ("The solutions are {0} and {1}".format(solt1, solt2)) [/code]
and then importing cmath for complex:
[code=python]#Solves Quadratic equation # ax**2(ax'squared') + bx + c = 0
#import complex numbers import cmath
a = float(input("Enter a: ")) b = float(input("Enter b: ")) c = float(input("Enter c: "))
#Finds the Discriminant d = (b**2) - (4*a*c)
#finds solutions solt1 = (-b-cmath.sqrt(d))/(2*a) solt2 = (-b+cmath.sqrt(d))/(2*a) print "The Discriminant is", d print ("The solutions are {0} and {1}".format(solt1, solt2)) [/code]
But I don't have enough knowledge towards this to get them to work together. Maybe if I inserted an if statement saying if the user inputs a complex number it would use cmath, but I'm not sure how that would turn out. Any insight would be appreciated. :rolleyes:

item.title: Quadratics
item.dc:creator: @ISUB ISUB
item.description:
@ISUB wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:4, topic:548090”][quote author=ISUB link=topic=666995.msg4460106#msg4460106 date=1417102569]
But I don’t have enough knowledge towards this to get them to work together.
Maybe if I inserted an if statement saying if the user inputs a complex number it would use cmath, but I’m not sure how that would turn out. Any insight would be appreciated. :rolleyes:
[/quote]

If the discriminant is negative you’ll end up with an imaginary number due to the sqrt, that’s how you know.[/quote]

That explains a lot, thanks justaguy!

Read full topic

If the discriminant is negative you’ll end up with an imaginary number due to the sqrt, that’s how you know.

item.title: Quadratics
item.dc:creator: @ISUB ISUB
item.description:
@ISUB wrote:

So, after yesterday experimenting around I kept trying to learn more into Python. Late last night my little brother needed some help in Alg2, he was doing Quadratic Equations with real and complex numbers. I thought that would be a nice project to work on trying to solve these in code.

One Problem though, I can’t seem to make both complex and real numbers a possibility in one program. I have found out how to get it to spit out real numbers, importing the math module:

[code=python]#Solves Quadratic equation

ax**2(ax’squared’) + bx + c = 0

#import real numbers
import math

a = float(input("Enter a: "))
b = float(input("Enter b: "))
c = float(input("Enter c: "))

#Finds the Discriminant
d = (b**2) - (4ac)

#finds solutions
solt1 = (-b-math.sqrt(d))/(2a)
solt2 = (-b+math.sqrt(d))/(2a)
print “The Discriminant is”, d
print (“The solutions are {0} and {1}”.format(solt1, solt2))
[/code]

and then importing cmath for complex:

[code=python]#Solves Quadratic equation

ax**2(ax’squared’) + bx + c = 0

#import complex numbers
import cmath

a = float(input("Enter a: "))
b = float(input("Enter b: "))
c = float(input("Enter c: "))

#Finds the Discriminant
d = (b**2) - (4ac)

#finds solutions
solt1 = (-b-cmath.sqrt(d))/(2a)
solt2 = (-b+cmath.sqrt(d))/(2a)
print “The Discriminant is”, d
print (“The solutions are {0} and {1}”.format(solt1, solt2))
[/code]

But I don’t have enough knowledge towards this to get them to work together.
Maybe if I inserted an if statement saying if the user inputs a complex number it would use cmath, but I’m not sure how that would turn out. Any insight would be appreciated. :rolleyes:

Read full topic
